moves.1. e4 c5 2. Bc4 Nc6 3. Nf3 g6 4. c3 Bg7: White wastes a move. Castling was best; and either 6. Be3 or 6. d4 was better than the text move.
moves.6... e6 7. O-O Nf6 8. h3 Bd7 9. Bf4 Qe7: White "unwastes" his previous sortie. Well, not. Better was 12. f4 first, grabbing space.
moves.12... Na5 13. Nc2 Rac8 14. a3 Nxc4 15. d: Inattentively grinding the gears somewhat. Better was 15. ...Ne4.
moves.16. Qd2 Bc6: Yes, I could have captured again here, but the pawn's not going anywhere, and the Bishop is a powerhouse on the long diagonal.
moves.17. Qd3 Bxe4 18. Qe2 Rfd8 19. Bh4 Bc6 20: Wrong Rook, technically, but it matters not. ...And just as an aside, how in the world can 2 chessplayers get 18 moves into a Sicilian (closed or not) and still have 15 of the original 16 pawns on the board?? Weird.
White's doing it to himself. This game should be a draw, ...after another couple hundred moves or so. But lulled (I suspect) by that big juicy rating of "1200" next to my screen-name, White assumes the win is in the bag and plays too aggressively, reaping the usual consequences.
moves.30. Ne3 Rc5: Have to keep appearances up: Black makes it look as if he's focused on winning the d-pawn. But he's not.
moves.35. Rd2d3 f4 36. Qg4 e4: White resigns. The c-pawn is about to be snapped off, putting Black 3 buttons to the good, and basically 2 pieces ahead because White's Knight is already entombed.
